title: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From - WSJ
text:

The U.S. and China are quietly talking about ways to resolve their showdown over trade. Top officials in Washington and Beijing have started negotiating over a range of ways to improve access by American companies to Chinese markets, the WSJ’s Lingling Wei and Bob Davis report. The talks may provide relief to those rattled by announcements last week of U.S. plans to hit China with tariffs and other measures aimed at addressing the U.S. $375 billion merchandise trade deficit with China. The negotiations cover a wide range of areas, including financial services and manufacturing, and are being led by Liu He, China’s economic czar, U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and U.S. trade representative Robert Lighthizer. The U.S. demands offer an opportunity for China to respond in very specific areas such as automotive trade, providing details Beijing has been looking for as the sharp rhetoric between the countries has escalated.
From farmers to tractor makers, companies across U.S. agriculture supply chains are bracing for a trade battle with China that many say couldn’t come at a worse time. Farm incomes this year are expected to slide to their lowest level since 2006, prolonging a downturn that has pushed some farmers out of business and eroded profits for seed, chemical and equipment companies. The WSJ’s Jesse Newman, Jacob Bunge and Benjamin Parkin write that exports have become more important to the U.S. farm economy as improved operations and efficient logistics networks made American farmers a premier global source of foodstuffs. China is the second-biggest customer for U.S. agricultural products after Canada, and its planned tariffs on pork, fruit, nuts and other goods could worsen the U.S. farm economy’s slump. Fewer buyers for U.S. crops could hurt manufacturers like Deere & Co., which last year reported modest improvement in sales of farm equipment after three years of declines amid falling crop prices.
U.S. crude exports are on a tear, but foreign trade houses appear to be reaping some of the biggest gains. Two years after Washington lifted a ban on exporting U.S. oil, a handful of international houses are dominating the buying and selling of that crude thanks to their greater expertise in trading and logistics. The WSJ’s Sarah McFarlane writes that shipments by three of the world’s top five oil traders accounted for 22% of U.S. crude exports in the past year. That’s partly the result of the fragmented nature of the U.S. shale industry, which can’t compete with more nimble, mostly Europe-based trade houses that buy and sell oil and ship it around the world. Some of the foreign traders’ edge in U.S. exports is expected to diminish as logistical issues are ironed out and U.S. infrastructure is built to handle outbound flows, but international traders have a foothold and say they’re in the business for the long haul.
SUPPLY CHAIN STRATEGIES The Yangshan Deep Water Port at the Port of Shanghai. Photo: Bloomberg News Anyone handling the shipping of live crocodiles fully understands the importance of packaging in supply chains. Exporters in Australia’s outback are turning to new strategies to get a bigger share of a high-value, high-risk business that takes crocs from marshlands to catwalks, including use of “travel pods” fashioned from plumbing pipes. The WSJ’s Rob Taylor writes the innovation is the latest tactic in a luxury goods market that turns crocodile skins into boots and handbags that can sell for $50,000 apiece and more—a booming business, especially in Asia. With luxury retailers looking for perfect skins for their final products, there’s an enormous premium on distribution that can preserve the animals and their skins without a scratch. Farmers have to be creative to move animals with as many as 72 razor-sharp teeth, notoriously bad attitudes and little interest in entering high-fashion supply chains.
QUOTABLE
‘ You open up the pods and you’ve got 70 pairs of crocodile eyes staring at you. For a heart-stopping moment you’re hoping like hell that the refrigeration worked and they don’t come rushing out in a waterfall of crocs. ’
—Adam Lever, an Australian crocodile farmer, on new shipping techniques.
Number of the Day 5% Decline in Shanghai Container Freight Index for shipping rates from Shanghai to European ports last week, the fourth straight weekly decline .
IN OTHER NEWS The U.S. and South Korea reached an agreement to amend their free trade deal and resolved a trade friction over U.S. steep tariffs on South Korean steel. (WSJ)
U.S. orders for durable goods rose 3.1% in February , the fastest rate in eight months. (WSJ)
Prices for soybeans, corn and other agriculture commodities turned sharply lower on global trade tensions . (WSJ)
The dollar is at its lowest level in nearly 18 months against the Japanese yen. (WSJ)
Sales of new U.S. homes slipped 0.6% in February . (WSJ)
Canadian retail sales rose less than expected in January on slowing automotive sales . (WSJ)
Japan’s SoftBank Group Corp. is looking to invest $1 billion in a Chinese truck load-matching company backed by internet giant Tencent Holdings Ltd. (WSJ)
Gun maker Remington Outdoor Co. filed for bankruptcy protection . (WSJ)
The Environmental Protection Agency tentatively concluded that future automobile emissions standards should be eased . (WSJ)
Nissan Motor Co. set a goal of selling one million battery-powered vehicles annually through the next five years . (WSJ)
Mexico’s Grupo Comercial Chedraui SA is buying Texas-based Fiesta Mart Inc., extending a wave of supermarket consolidation . (WSJ)
The International Longshoremen’s Association and port terminal employers said they have made “significant progress” on a six-year labor contract . (Journal of Commerce)
Dry-bulk carrier earnings are projected to rise this year as fleet growth is set to be the lowest in a decade . (Lloyd’s List)
Greece concluded the sale of a 67% stake in the Thessaloniki port to a consortium that includes French shipping line CMA CGM SA. (Reuters)
Mexico’s Coca-Cola Femsa is shutting its Altamirano distribution center because of lack of security in the southwestern city. (Mexico Daily News)
Amazon.com Inc. is looking for larger spaces for Whole Foods grocery stores so they can do double duty as distribution centers . (Bloomberg)
Amazon is setting plans for an 855,000-square-foot distribution center in the Grand Rapids, Mich., area. (MiBiz)
The new U.S. tax law is helping owner-operators buy their own trucks without having to go through lease-purchase programs. (Commercial Carrier Journal)
FedEx Corp. dropped plans to build a FedEx Ground sorting center in Greenwood, Ind. (RTV)
French retailer Carrefour is starting delivery services next month . (Les Echos)
Amtrak in a quarterly “report card” rated Canadian National Railway Ltd. as the worst major freight railroad for track services. (Progressive Railroading)
Amazon won a patent for a delivery drone that can respond to people screaming and flailing their arms . (Washington Post)
